There are several empires throughout history that ultimately did more harm than good to the territories they controlled, but my “first prize” goes to the Belgian colonial Empire. Belgium was one of the latest players in the grand colonial empire “game”, but arrived just in time to contest the colonization of Africa, managing to secure a massive amount of territory in the Congo (modern Democratic Republic of Congo) and a few other territories around it, plus a foothold in China after the latter was essentially segregated into European spheres of influence. The Belgian rule over Congo wasn’t merely about transferring power and securing a colonial domain, it was about sheer resource extraction and local populace exploitation. Belgium being a small country with few natural resources used the natural riches and resources of the Congo to fund its industrialization process and fulfill their ambitions into becoming a relevant colonial power (fat chance). The process was horrid and inhumane in several ways: First of all, King Leopold II essentially owned the Congo as his own property for over 20 years between 1885 and 1908 when it became an official colony under the domain of Belgium. He used the Congo solely as a means to enhance his riches and make a profit out of the occupation. Imagine a feudal lord, but owning a land of over 50 million people without any overarching authority. Secondly, the Congo peoples were used as nigh-slaves to gather resources such as ivory and rubber. The labour was enforced via use of extreme violence: They tortured, mutilated and even downright murdered millions of natives for this purpose. Thirdly, a factor outside of Belgian control was the spread of diseases like smallpox among the inhabitants who were not predisposed to them. The result of this along with the aforementioned forced labour practices was an estimated 10 million deaths which was approximately 20–25% of the entire local population of that period. And lastly, there was heavily-monitored and strict racial segregation that lasted in some forms even up to the late period before the Congo’s independence. Now, Belgium didn’t do just harm, for example it played a big role in the later urbanization of the country and the development of a European-style economic activity which helped many natives to rise from poverty. However, that was only instigated in the latter 10–15 years of the Belgian Congo and did next to nothing to make up for the brutal exploitation of the late 19th/early 20th century. A testament to the cruelty of the Belgian rule is perhaps the most famous of “what a human is capable to do to another human being” stories, “Heart of Darkness” by Joseph Conrad who used his own personal experiences in the Congo as inspiration for the plot.
